name: hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation | hard coal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/7999/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg hard coal (useable output) in the specific region with an energy content of 17.3 MJ/kg pit coal. Life time is assumed to be 20 years for operation. Additionally, 100 years of life time are taken into account due to the assumption that land after operation is destroyed and not useable for a long time. Thus, land recultivation is not considered in the dataset. After 120 years, revegetation of land is expected. This dataset is based on various literature studies on material flows and energy use. Data regarding land use for operational areas for infrastructure, extraction areas and dump areas have been estimated. Both open pit (58%) and underground mines (42%) in North America are taken into account in this dataset. Land use for affected water supply areas only represent rough estimations. Data regarding land use are not valid for specific regions, for this, higher uncertainties are considered. In this dataset infrastructure requirements are applied to total production over the life time. For this, the total production has to be estimated. A total production over life time of 3*10^10 kg is assumed. This figure represents an average value and is not representative for single mines or specific conditions.

Mining process starting from hard coal, in ground.

This activity ends with 1 kg hard coal at the coal mine. This dataset includes land use during operation, emissions to water and air, water extraction during pumping, energy requirements for operation, explosives, as well as the deposition of spoil. This dataset doesn’t include noise emissions; however they are expected to be wide-ranging. The amount of geothermal energy directly or indirectly emitted to air by extraction of hot pit water or increased evaporation is not considered due to the lack of data.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Opencast mining: Compared to lignite, hard coal seams are much thinner but in most cases up to 20 seams are located one above the other. In general seam thickness ranges from 2 to 10 meters; the seams are located up to a depth of 100 meters. In hard coal opencast mines often lorries and bucket excavators are used. Due to the fact that hard coal is embedded in hard rock formations and hard coal itself is rather hard, the rock formations have to be blasted, thus significant amounts of explosives are required.;Underground mining: In underground mines seam thickness ranges from 0.7 to 5 meters. It is also possible to extract seams which are located one upon the other. Seams with a thickness below 0.7 meters can not be mined cost effectively. Depths range from below 100 meters u to 1000 meters. ;;In this dataset it is assumed that the total amount of coal is treated, particularly for export coal high calorific values and low sulfuric contents are required. Data regarding mine waste is based on Hinrichs. ;;In this dataset a processing efficiency factor of 95 % (opencast mining) and 92 % (underground mining) is assumed. Mine waste is partly recycled or disposed. Energetic use of flotation tailings in fluidized bed combustion is not included in the dataset due to insufficient information and insignificant amounts; assuming complete utilization, only 20 % of combustible matter can be recycled.

Estimation. In opencast mines coal output amounts to 90-95 %; in underground mines depending on technology and geological conditions coal output ranges from 40 to 80 %. Due to the fact that only extracted coal is considered as resource, no mean value has to be estimated. The heat value of pit hard coal ranges from 15 to 30 MJ/kg. 

In this dataset 58 % of coal is mined in opencast mines. 

At coal mining, fossil resources are taken from the lithosphere. The energy content of these resources is used to calculate the CED (Cumulative Energy Demand). Energy content of hard coal varies for the different mining regions. Based on information about the mass of pit coal per t coal equivalent (1 t coal equivalent equals 29.308 GJ) the energy content of pit coal can be calculated. The calculated values are in accordance with data given in Hinrichs. In this mining region a gross calorific value of 19.3 MJ/kg pit coal can be estimated. Based on the results for the different mining regions and weighted with the annual total production an average value of 19.1 MJ/kg can be calculated. This figure represents the gross calorific value for the exchange “coal, hard, unspecified in ground”. 

To calculate the CED a correction factor has to be used in order to consider differences between calorific values for different hard coals. This factor (i.e. relative resource extraction) corresponds to the gross calorific value of respective mining region divided by the average gross calorific value worldwide. 

In this region 1,321 kg pit coal/ kg useable output are extracted. 


Further references:

Frischknecht R., Jungbluth N., Althaus H.-J., Doka G., Dones R., Hischier R., Hellweg S., Humbert S., Margni M., Nemecek T. and Spielmann M. (2004c) Implementation of Life Cycle Impact Assessment Methods. Final report ecoinvent 2000 No. 3. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, retrieved from: www.ecoinvent.ch <http://www.ecoinvent.ch>.

Estimation. Regarding particulates, only those are considered which are not emitted during the combustion process and which are not deposited within the mining area. In AP 42 information about situational particle emission calculations and characteristical particle size distribution are given. 90 % of dust particles show sizes between 15 and 30 um, 10 % of dust particles are smaller than 15 um, 6 % of dust particles are smaller than 10 um and between 0.2 % und 1 % are smaller than 2.54 um. Regarding underground mining marginal emissions due to ventilation and slightly more emissions due to coal handling and the actual treatment step are estimated. Regarding opencast mining sharply increased emissions due to huge mining machines, lorries and open pits are estimated. Furthermore, emissions depend on climatic conditions (wind, precipitation, temperature) and the characteristics of coal (water content). In the literature figures regarding particle emissions range from 22 to 75 g/t. In this dataset particle emissions of 36 g/t are considered.

In various literature sources no information about other emissions emitted during underground mining are given respectively insignificant amounts are assumed, even though backfill processes show high specific emissions. 

In this dataset the following particle emissions factors are estimated: 

Particle emissions underground mining incl. treatment: 0.1 kg/t useable output

Particle emissions opencast mining incl. treatment: 0.4 kg/t useable output.

All emissions are assumed to be fly ash coarse particles (i.e. > 10 um).

Further references:

Calculated as the sum of fugitive CH4 emissions from mining, processing, storage and transporation of coal reported in the categories “1.B. 1. a. Coal mining and handling” and “1.B. 1. b. Solid fuel transformation” of the National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Reports of Annex I Countries (NIRs) in 2016  for Canada and USA divided by the 2016 production volume of Canada and the USA. The total fugitive methane emissions from coal mining and handling were 50 140 t in Canada and 2 420 580 t in the USA, with total hard coal production of 60 Mio t and 666 Mio t, respectively. Retrieved from the respective common reporting format (CRF) files released in 2017. Reference(s): The respective National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Reports and common reporting format (CRF), released in 2018, of Annex I countries can be downloaded at http://unfccc.int/national_reports/annex_i_ghg_inventories/national_inventories_submissions/items/10116.php, last accessed July 2018

Electricity is often derived from mine-mouth power plants, which are powered with low-grad coal (i.e. coal with higher ash content and lower heat value). High voltage electricity (UCTE-mix) is used. Emissions in this dataset are likely to be underestimated due to the following assumptions: 50 % of hard coal is mined outside the UCTE-region, electricity supply in these regions is primarily based on fossil energy sources and environmental standards are often below European standards. However, these assumptions are not considered in the dataset because all energy systems obtain electricity at European power plants. This would considerably increase loading of imported coal.

Estimation. Regarding radon emissions extensive measurements were taken to develop a measurement methodology and to review operating conditions. (Müller et al. 1992) 

Radon concentrations in air flow when leaving the shaft installations are most important to estimate specific radon emissions. Immission measurements at different measuring points (also badly aerated sites) show figures between 80 and 500 Bq/m3 (i.e. mean value of 200 Bq/m3). It was not possible to allocate specific air flow amounts per t extracted coal. According to about 20 % of the radon concentration of coal plus twice the concentration are emitted via overburden, which corresponds to 12 Bq/kg coal. (UNSCEAR 1988) No differentiation between opencast and underground mines has been made due to the lack of data. This figure is used in this dataset. 

Further references:
